   Assessment and Plan
   72 yo female h/o DM, HLD, HTN, Afib with RVR, s/p pacemaker and sarcoid
   presents  with acute heart failure leading to flash pulmonary edema.
   Patient also with AFib with RVR causing hypotension. Also with mild
   troponin increase of 0.12 (peaked at 0.27 in OSH), ischemic changes on
   EKG (TWI) : Sent for cath and found 2 vessel disease, s/p BMS to LAD.
   .
   # CORONARIES: NSTEMI: found to have 2 vessel disease on cardiac cath.
   s/p BMS to the mid LAD. ? whether this was a primary coronary event or
   demand [**1-28**] RVR as pt. had acute heart failure yesterday and still has
   not significantly increased her troponin, would have expected large
   bump by now if infarct large enough to cause LV failure. EKG does
   appear to be c/w s/p anterior infarct.
   -Integrillin gtt until 18 hours post cath (stop at 1100)
   -Plavix 75 mg [**Hospital1 7**]
   - Start Aspirin desensitisation protocal
   - Simvistatin 80 mg daily
   - Start metroprolol low dose later today.
   -Hold ACE for now, given her hypotension and dye in cath
   - TTE in am to check for WMA
   .
   # PUMP: Noted to have EF of 60-70% on [**5-27**]. Current BNP elevated to
   [**Numeric Identifier 8933**].  Fluid overload possibly secondary afib with RVR; this is likely
   the etiology behind her flash pulmonary edema.
   -Will hold diuresis as patient is hypotensive and on Phenylephrine
   -Once stable, will consider diuresing
   -FU TTE today
   .
   # RHYTHM: Patient with h/o afib with RVR, presents to unit in afib with
   RVR and hemodynamically unstable.
   -Dilt gtt started, bolus of 20 mg with infusion of [**5-15**] mg/hr as
   tolerated maintain HR < 110;
   - Since patient has a DDD pacemaker, will give as much nodal agents as
   needed for RVR, as patient will be paced out of bradycardia.
   - Neo gtt to maintain MAP > 60
   - Start low dose metroprolol later today after ASA desensitization.
   - Monitor on telemetry
   - INR elevated to 2.3; continue home dose of coumadin as patient is at
   goal, but will hold heparin gtt.
   .
   # Respiratory Failure: Intubated s/p flash pulmonary edema in OSH;
   possibly secondary to Acute dCHF
   -intubated on AC; Will attempt PS today and ultimately wean from vent
   when HD stable; RISBI overnight was 29
   - Check ABG's in AM
   - Start Lasix 20 mg IV, FU I/Os adjust as needed.
   - CXR in AM
   -  Attempt extubation today.
   # Respiratory Acidosis with Metabolic Compensation: Patient h/o COPD on
   home oxygen secondary to sarcoidosis. Acid/Base disturbance likely
   secondary to COPD, as patient may be a CO2 retainer.
   -Continue to monitor with ABG's
   -Adjust major acid/base disturbances with ventilation manipulation
   .
   # Leukocytosis: Patient had wbc in OSH of 8.4 on [**7-15**], currently  24.2.
   Patient spiked to 101.1, and CXR shows new middle lobe infilitrate.
   Also, C.diff cannot be ruled out as pt. w/ h/o diarrhea and acutely
   high WBC.
   - BCX, UCx and sputum culture, and C. diff toxin pending
   -Will start empiric treatment of VAP since new infiltrate shown on CXR;
   will start 7 day course of vanc/cefepime: will need ID approval
   -Since white count is markedly elevated and patient has h/o diarrhea,
   cannot exclude C. diff. Will start empiric treatment with flaygl
   pending c. diff toxin results.
   .
   # Sarcoidosis: On home O2 3LNC; currently stable; patient intubated
   - Continue Prednisone 5 mg qAM and 2.5 mg qPM
   - H/o hypercalcemia -> will continue fosamax q weekly
   .
   # Diabetes type 2: Will hold metformin and glipizide for now
   -Start humulog ISS for more predictable control
   -FSBS qachs
   .
   # Dyslipidemia: Do not have recent lipid panel.
   -Will hold zetia
   -Will check lipid panel this AM
   -Start simvistatin 80 mg daily
   # HTN: patient currently hypotensive
   -Currently normotensive.
   # Hypothyroidism:
   -Continue Synthroid at 25 mcg daily
   # Depression:
   -Continue Paroxetine 10 mg daily
   # GERD:
   -Start H2 blocker (Famotidine) as PPI interacts with Plavix
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: NPO for now; if fails weaning today, consider tube feeds;
   if successful extubation, attempt po diet
   Glycemic Control:  ISS
   Lines:
   Multi Lumen - [**2182-7-16**] 07:06 PM left femoral
   20 Gauge - [**2182-7-17**] 12:50 AM
   Consider PICC line.
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT:  boots, therapeutic INR
   Stress ulcer:  Famotidine 20 mg daily
   VAP:  HOB 30 degrees
   Comments:
   Communication:  Comments:  Husband [**Name (NI) 135**] [**Name (NI) 2415**]: [**Telephone/Fax (1) 8934**] (health
   care proxy)
   Code status: Full code
   Disposition:  CCU for now
   ------ Protected Section ------
   Cardiology Teaching Physician Note
   On this day I saw, examined and was physically present with the
   resident / fellow for the key portions of the services provided. I
   agree with the above note and plans.
   I would add the following remarks:
   History
   Rapid af leading to troponin elevation in setting of a tight distal lad
   lesion that was stented.  She has severe mulitiorgan sarcoidosis with
   muiltiple potential cardiac manifestation including heart block (at one
   time) requiring ddd pacer, atrial arrhythmias for which she was on
   sotalol for a while; even her cad could possibly be from sarcoid but
   obviously most likely from her usual risk factors of htn,
   hyperlipidemia, obesity, age, and diabetes.  I suspect that her atrial
   arrhythmias will be difficult to manage so we should get an eps
   consult.
   Physical Examination
   echo shows apical hk of the lv and apical akinesis of the rv with
   severe pulm htn (interestingly the rhc demonstrated only mild elevation
   of pulm vasc resistance which means that most of the blame for the pulm
   htn rests on diastolic dysfunction of the left ventricle)
   Medical Decision Making
   Since it is of paramount importance to maintain sinus rhythm (or at
   very least a well-controlled ventricular rate in af), and since she has
   lung disease possibly precluding the drug of choice (amiodarone), we
   will get an eps consult.
   ------ Protected Section Addendum Entered By:[**Name (NI) **] [**Name (NI) **]  on:[**2182-7-17**]
   11:14 ------
Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 72-year-old female with a history of diabetes mellitus, hyperlipidemia, hypertension, atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response, and sarcoidosis. She presents with acute heart failure leading to flash pulmonary edema. The patient also has a mild increase in troponin levels, indicative of possible ischemic changes on EKG. A cardiac catheterization revealed two-vessel disease, and the patient underwent percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) with stenting of the mid-left anterior descending artery.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient is intubated and on mechanical ventilation due to flash pulmonary edema. There is a concern for continued respiratory failure, and weaning from the ventilator may be challenging.
2. Atrial Fibrillation with Rapid Ventricular Response: The patient's history of atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response may complicate her management, particularly in the setting of heart failure. An electrophysiology consult has been requested to optimize her antiarrhythmic therapy.
3. Ventricular Arrhythmias: Given the patient's history of sarcoidosis and the presence of right ventricular akinesis on echocardiography, there is a concern for the development of ventricular arrhythmias.
4. Diabetic Complications: The patient has diabetes mellitus, and her glycemic control needs to be carefully monitored in the setting of acute illness.
5. Sarcoid

Summary:
The patient is a 72-year-old female with a history of diabetes mellitus, hyperlipidemia, hypertension, atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (AFib with RVR), and sarcoidosis. She presents with acute heart failure leading to flash pulmonary edema and hypotension due to AFib with RVR. The patient also had an acute myocardial infarction (NSTEMI) with two-vessel disease, for which she underwent percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) with bare-metal stent placement in the mid-left anterior descending artery (LAD).

The patient's current medications include Plavix 75 mg, simvastatin 80 mg daily, metoprolol (low dose), and diltiazem infusion. She is also receiving integrilin through a continuous infusion.

The patient's vital signs include a temperature of 38.4°C (101.1°F), heart rate ranging from 69 to 137 beats per minute (bpm), blood pressure ranging from 87/36 to 126/48 mmHg, respiratory rate of 17 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 96% on supplemental oxygen via an endotracheal tube.    72 yo female h/o DM, HLD, HTN, Afib with RVR, s/p pacemaker and sarcoid
   presents  with acute heart failure leading to flash pulmonary edema.
   Patient also with AFib with RVR causing hypotension. Also with mild
   troponin increase of 0.12 (peaked at 0.27 in OSH), ischemic changes on

   .
   # CORONARIES: NSTEMI: found to have 2 vessel disease on cardiac cath.
   s/p BMS to the mid LAD. ? whether this was a primary coronary event or
   demand [**1-28**] RVR as pt. had acute heart failure yesterday and still has
   not significantly increased her troponin, would have expected large
   bump by now if infarct large enough to cause LV failure. EKG does
   appear to be c/w s/p anterior infarct.
   -Integrillin gtt until 18 hours post cath (stop at 1100)
   -Plavix 75 mg [**Hospital1 7**]
   - Start Aspirin desensitisation protocal
   - Simvistatin 80 mg daily
   - Start metroprolol low dose later today.
   -Hold ACE for now, given her hypotension and dye in cath
   - TTE in am to check for WMA
   .
   # PUMP: Noted to have EF of 60-70% on [**5-27**]. Current BNP elevated to
   [**Numeric Identifier 8933**].  Fluid overload possibly secondary afib with RVR; this is likely
   the etiology behind her flash pulmonary edema.
   -Will hold diuresis as patient is hypotensive and on Phenylephrine
   -Once stable, will consider diuresing
   -FU TTE today
   .
   # RHYTHM: Patient with h/o afib with RVR, presents to unit in afib with
   RVR and hemodynamically unstable.
   -Dilt gtt started, bolus of 20 mg with infusion of [**5-15**] mg/hr as
   tolerated maintain HR < 110;
   - Since patient has a DDD pacemaker, will give as much nodal agents as
   needed for RVR, as patient will be paced out of bradycardia.
   - Neo gtt to maintain MAP > 60
   - Start low dose metroprolol later today after ASA desensitization.
   - Monitor on telemetry
   - INR elevated to 2.3; continue home dose of coumadin as patient is at
   goal, but will hold heparin gtt.
   .
   # Respiratory Failure: Intubated s/p flash pulmonary edema in OSH;
   possibly secondary to Acute dCHF
   -intubated on AC; Will attempt PS today and ultimately wean from vent
   when HD stable; RISBI overnight was 29
   - Check ABG's in AM
   - Start Lasix 20 mg IV, FU I/Os adjust as needed.
   - CXR in AM
   -  Attempt extubation today.
   # Respiratory Acidosis with Metabolic Compensation: Patient h/o COPD on
   home oxygen secondary to sarcoidosis. Acid/Base disturbance likely
   secondary to COPD, as patient may be a CO2 retainer.
   -Continue to monitor with ABG's
   -Adjust major acid/base disturbances with ventilation manipulation
   .
   # Leukocytosis: Patient had wbc in OSH of 8.4 on [**7-15**], currently  24.2.
   Patient spiked to 101.1, and CXR shows new middle lobe infilitrate.
   Also, C.diff cannot be ruled out as pt. w/ h/o diarrhea and acutely
   high WBC.

   -Will start empiric treatment of VAP since new infiltrate shown on CXR;
   will start 7 day course of vanc/cefepime: will need ID approval
   -Since white count is markedly elevated and patient has h/o diarrhea,
   cannot exclude C. diff. Will start empiric treatment with flaygl
   pending c. diff toxin results.
   .
   # Sarcoidosis: On home O2 3LNC; currently stable; patient intubated
   - Continue Prednisone 5 mg qAM and 2.5 mg qPM
   - H/o hypercalcemia -> will continue fosamax q weekly
   .
   # Diabetes type 2: Will hold metformin and glipizide for now
   -Start humulog ISS for more predictable control
   -FSBS qachs
   .
   # Dyslipidemia: Do not have recent lipid panel.
   -Will hold zetia

   -Start simvistatin 80 mg daily
   # HTN: patient currently hypotensive
   -Currently normotensive.
   # Hypothyroidism:

   # Depression:
   -Continue Paroxetine 10 mg daily

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 72-year-old female with a history of diabetes mellitus, hyperlipidemia, hypertension, atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (AFib with RVR), sarcoidosis, and depression. She presented with acute heart failure leading to flash pulmonary edema, and her condition has been unstable with hypotension and tachycardia. She underwent cardiac catheterization and was found to have two-vessel coronary artery disease, for which she received a bare-metal stent in the mid-left anterior descending artery. The patient is currently intubated and on mechanical ventilation due to respiratory failure, and she has been diagnosed with respiratory acidosis with metabolic compensation.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Cardiac Complications: Given the patient's history of AFib with RVR, coronary artery disease, and recent stenting, there is a risk of recurrent arrhythmias, myocardial ischemia, and congestive heart failure.
2. Pulmonary Complications: Due to the patient's respiratory failure and flash pulmonary edema, she may be at risk for pneumonia, ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), and worsening respiratory distress.
3. Infection: The patient's elevated white blood cell count and symptoms of diarrhea suggest a possible infection, such as Clostridium difficile (C. diff) colitis. Additionally, there is a concern for ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) due to her intubation.

She presented with acute heart failure leading to flash pulmonary edema. The patient also had an elevated troponin level, indicating possible myocardial injury, and underwent cardiac catheterization which revealed two-vessel disease. She subsequently underwent stenting of the mid-left anterior descending artery.

The patient's current conditions include:
1. Coronary artery disease: The patient has evidence of two-vessel coronary artery disease, treated with percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) and placement of a bare-metal stent in the LAD.
2. Acute heart failure: The patient's acute heart failure episode resulted in flash pulmonary edema, for which she was intubated and placed on mechanical ventilation.
3. Atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response: The patient continues to have episodes of AFib with RVR, requiring management with diltiazem infusion to control heart rate.
4. Hypotension: The patient has been hypotensive, necessitating the use of phenylephrine and Neo volume expanders to maintain adequate blood pressure.

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 72-year-old female with a history of diabetes mellitus, hyperlipidemia, hypertension, atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (AFib with RVR), and sarcoidosis. She presented with acute heart failure leading to flash pulmonary edema. The patient also had AFib with RVR causing hypotension. There was a mild increase in troponin levels, indicating ischemic changes on EKG (Twi). She underwent cardiac catheterization and was found to have two-vessel disease, for which she received a bare-metal stent (BMS) in the mid-left anterior descending artery (LAD). 

The patient's current medications include Plavix 75 mg, simvastatin 80 mg daily, and low-dose metoprolol. She is being monitored closely for any signs of complications, such as ventricular arrhythmias, respiratory failure, or infection.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Ventricular arrhythmias: Given the patient's history of AFib with RVR and recent myocardial infarction, there is a risk of developing ventricular arrhythmias. Close monitoring with telemetry is essential.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient is currently intubated due to flash pulmonary edema secondary to acute decompensated heart failure (dCHF). Weaning from the ventilator will be attempted once her hemodynamic stability improves.
3. Infection

   72 yo female h/o DM, HLD, HTN, Afib with RVR, s/p pacemaker and sarcoid
   presents with acute heart failure leading to flash pulmonary edema.
   Patient with multiple episodes of AFib with RVR and hypotension since
   admission, including yesterday evening. She was sent for cath and found
   to have 2 vessel disease, s/p BMS to LAD.  She now is intubated, on
   some sedation, and continues to have volatile blood pressure control
   and episodes of Afib with RVR.
   .

   hemodynamic instability.
   - Dilt gtt restarted this morning at 10mg/hr, will titrate to maintain
   HR < 110;
   - Since patient has a DDD pacemaker, will not hold back on nodal agents
   as needed for RVR, as patient will be paced out of bradycardia.
   - Start Lopressor
   - DC Diltiazem
   - Monitor on telemetry
   - INR at goal of [**1-29**] today (INR=2.5), will continue home dose of
   coumadin
   - Will continue to rate control per EP
   - Contact outside cardiologist and pulmonologist for ?amiodarone
   # CORONARIES: NSTEMI: found to have 2 vessel disease on cardiac cath
   s/p BMS to the mid LAD. ? whether this was a primary coronary event or
   demand [**1-28**] RVR as pt. had acute heart failure yesterday and still has
   not significantly increased her troponin, would have expected large
   bump by now if infarct large enough to cause LV failure. EKG does
   appear to be c/w s/p anterior infarct.   TTE yesterday showed normal
   EF, focal hypokinesis of apical free wall of RV, and severe pulmonary
   systolic hypertension.
   - Integrillin gtt has now stopped
   - Completed ASA desensitization yesterday
   - Switched Plavix 75 mg to daily instead of [**Hospital1 7**]
   - Simvistatin 80 mg daily
   - Start metroprolol low dose later today if BP tolerates
   - Hold ACE for now, given her hypotension, dye in cath, and bump in
   creatinine
   .

   possibly secondary afib with RVR; this is likely the etiology behind
   her flash pulmonary edema.  She is likely still fluid overloaded, but
   has been hypotensive with MAPs in the 50
s overnight.
   - Will hold diuresis as patient is hypotensive and currently in Afib
   with RVR
   - Once stable, will consider diuresing again
   - Started on stress dose steroids in order to supplement BP given
   possibility of adrenal insufficiency
   .
   # Respiratory Failure: Intubated s/p flash pulmonary edema in OSH;
   possibly secondary to Acute dCHF and complicated by severe pulmonary
   hypertension
   - intubated on AC; can attempt PS again today and ultimately wean from
   vent when HD stable
   - Serial ABG's
   - CXR in AM
   -  Will avoid albuterol [**1-28**] terbutaline allergy
   .
   #Anemia: Continues to trend down. Unable to guaiac stool (no BM). At
   this time thought to be secondary to marrow suppression.
   - Trend HCT
   # Respiratory Acidosis with Metabolic Compensation: Patient h/o COPD on
   home oxygen secondary to sarcoidosis. Acid/Base disturbance likely
   secondary to COPD, as patient may be a CO2 retainer.
   - Continue to monitor with ABG's
   - Adjust major acid/base disturbances with ventilation manipulation
   .
   # Fever/Leukocytosis: Patient still febrile to 102.2 with resolution of
   her leukocytosis (WBC 8.7 this am).  Being treated with Vanc/Cefepime
   and now with positive blood cultures of GPC.  Urine cx neg, sputum
   showed oropharyngeal flora.
   - Continue Vanc/cefepime (Day [**2-2**])
   - Continue Flagyl for possible C Diff infection, as cannot rule that
   out
   - Antibiotics approval received for Vanc/Cefepime
   .
   # Acute Renal Failure: Patient with bump in creatinine today to 1.5
   (from 1.1 yesterday), likely prerenal etiology as consistently
   hypotensive overnight.  [**Month (only) 51**] also be related to dye given during cath,
   and possible septic shock.
   - Will calculate FeUrea to evaluated for prerenal etiology
   - Monitor creatinine daily
   - Continue to support BP for increased renal perfusion
   - Rate control her Afib to increased forward flow from heart
   # Sarcoidosis: On home O2 3LNC; currently stable; patient intubated
   - Switched to stress dose steroids
   - H/o hypercalcemia -> will continue fosamax q weekly
   .
   # Diabetes type 2: Will hold metformin and glipizide for now.
   Fingersticks 231-332, not well-controlled.
   -Start humulog ISS for more predictable control, will add lantus dose
   for basal insulin

   - Holding zetia for now

Summary:
The patient is a 72-year-old female with a history of diabetes, hyperlipidemia, hypertension, atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (AFib with RVR), and sarcoidosis. She presented with acute heart failure leading to flash pulmonary edema and was found to have two-vessel coronary artery disease during cardiac catheterization, for which she underwent stenting of the left anterior descending artery. The patient continues to have episodes of AFib with RVR and hypotension, requiring frequent medical interventions.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Hypotension: The patient's blood pressure has been unstable, requiring the use of various medications such as Lasix, Diltiazem, and neosynephrine to maintain adequate mean arterial pressure (MAP).
2. Atrial Fibrillation with Rapid Ventricular Response (AFib with RVR): The patient has had multiple episodes of AFib with RVR, which can lead to hemodynamic instability and requires rate control measures.
3. Pulmonary Edema: The patient initially presented with flash pulmonary edema, likely secondary to acute decompensated heart failure (dCHF). She required intubation and mechanical ventilation to support her respiratory function.
4. Acute Renal Failure: The patient's serum creatinine level has increased from 1.1 to 1.5, indicating a possible prerenal etiology due to hypotension. This may be exacerbated by the

   72 yo female h/o DM, HLD, HTN, Afib with RVR, s/p pacemaker and sarcoid
   presents with acute heart failure leading to flash pulmonary edema.
   Patient with multiple episodes of AFib with RVR and hypotension since
   admission, including yesterday evening. She was sent for cath and found
   to have 2 vessel disease, s/p BMS to LAD.  She now is intubated, on
   some sedation, and continues to have volatile blood pressure control.
   .
   # RHYTHM: Patient with h/o afib with RVR, presents to unit in afib with
   RVR and hemodynamically unstable.
   -Dilt gtt started, bolus of 20 mg with infusion of [**5-15**] mg/hr as
   tolerated maintain HR < 110;
   - Since patient has a DDD pacemaker, will give as much nodal agents as
   needed for RVR, as patient will be paced out of bradycardia.
   - Neo gtt to maintain MAP > 60
   - Start low dose metroprolol later today after ASA desensitization.
   - Monitor on telemetry
   - INR elevated to 2.3; continue home dose of coumadin as patient is at
   goal, but will hold heparin gtt.
   # CORONARIES: NSTEMI: found to have 2 vessel disease on cardiac cath.
   s/p BMS to the mid LAD. ? whether this was a primary coronary event or
   demand [**1-28**] RVR as pt. had acute heart failure yesterday and still has
   not significantly increased her troponin, would have expected large
   bump by now if infarct large enough to cause LV failure. EKG does
   appear to be c/w s/p anterior infarct.
   - Integrillin gtt until 18 hours post cath (stop at 1100)
   - Plavix 75 mg [**Hospital1 7**]
   - Start Aspirin desensitisation protocal
   - Simvistatin 80 mg daily
   - Start metroprolol low dose later today.
   - Hold ACE for now, given her hypotension and dye in cath
   - TTE in am to check for WMA
   .
   # PUMP: Noted to have EF of 60-70% on [**5-27**]. Current BNP elevated to
   [**Numeric Identifier 8933**].  Fluid overload possibly secondary afib with RVR; this is likely
   the etiology behind her flash pulmonary edema.
   - Will hold diuresis as patient is hypotensive and on Phenylephrine
   - Once stable, will consider diuresing
   - FU TTE today
   .
   # Respiratory Failure: Intubated s/p flash pulmonary edema in OSH;
   possibly secondary to Acute dCHF
   -intubated on AC; Will attempt PS today and ultimately wean from vent
   when HD stable; RISBI overnight was 29
   - Check ABG's in AM
   - Start Lasix 20 mg IV, FU I/Os adjust as needed.
   - CXR in AM
   - Attempt extubation today.
   - Avoid albuterol [**1-28**] terbutaline allergy
   # Respiratory Acidosis with Metabolic Compensation: Patient h/o COPD on
   home oxygen secondary to sarcoidosis. Acid/Base disturbance likely
   secondary to COPD, as patient may be a CO2 retainer.
   - Continue to monitor with ABG's
   - Adjust major acid/base disturbances with ventilation manipulation
   .

   cannot exclude C. diff. Will start empiric treatment with flaygl

   - Antibiotics approval received for Vanc/Cefepime
   .
   # Acute Renal Failure: Patient with bump in creatinine today to 1.5
   (from 1.1 yesterday)
   # Sarcoidosis: On home O2 3LNC; currently stable; patient intubated
   - Continue Prednisone 5 mg qAM and 2.5 mg qPM
   - H/o hypercalcemia -> will continue fosamax q weekly
   .
   # Diabetes type 2: Will hold metformin and glipizide for now
   -Start humulog ISS for more predictable control
   -FSBS qachs
   .
   # Dyslipidemia: Do not have recent lipid panel.
   -Will hold zetia
   -Will check lipid panel this AM
   -Start simvistatin 80 mg daily
   # HTN: patient currently hypotensive
   -Currently normotensive.
   # Hypothyroidism:
   -Continue Synthroid at 25 mcg daily
   # Depression:
   -Continue Paroxetine 10 mg daily

Summary: The patient is a 72-year-old female with a history of diabetes, hypertension, and heart disease, presenting with acute heart failure leading to flash pulmonary edema. She has been intubated due to respiratory failure and is currently on mechanical ventilation. The patient has had multiple episodes of atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response and hypotension since admission, including yesterday evening. She underwent cardiac catheterization and was found to have two-vessel disease, for which she received a bare-metal stent to the left anterior descending artery. The patient's blood cultures grew Gram-positive cocci in clusters, indicating a possible line-related infection. She has also shown leukocytosis and a high white blood cell count, which may be indicative of an infection. The patient has been started on empirical treatment for ventilator-associated pneumonia and Clostridium difficile infection. Her renal function has worsened, with an increase in creatinine from 1.1 to 1.5. She is also being treated for acute renal failure. Other medical conditions include sarcoidosis, dyslipidemia, depression, and gastroesophageal reflux disease. The patient's family has been informed of her condition and code status. She is currently in the critical care unit.

Summary:
The patient is a 72-year-old female with a history of diabetes mellitus, hyperlipidemia, hypertension, atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (AFib with RVR), sarcoidosis, and depression. She presented with acute heart failure leading to flash pulmonary edema and was found to have 2 vessel disease during cardiac catheterization, subsequently receiving bare metal stent (BMS) placement in the left anterior descending artery (LAD). The patient continues to experience episodes of AFib with RVR and hypotension since admission.

The patient's current medications include metoprolol 100mg orally three times a day, lisinopril 20mg orally daily, aspirin 81mg orally daily, atorvastatin 80mg orally daily, and simvastatin 80mg orally daily. She is also on stress dose steroids due to the possibility of adrenal insufficiency.

The patient's vital signs include a temperature of 102.2°F, heart rate of 76 beats per minute (bpm), blood pressure of 109/41mmHg, respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 89-93% on a fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 51%. She is intubated and on assist-control ventilation with a tidal volume (Vt) set at 450mL, positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 8cmH2O, and fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 50%. The plateau pressure is 20cmH2O.

The patient's arterial blood gas (ABG) analysis shows a pH of 7.40, partial pressure of carbon dioxide (PaCO2) of 33mmHg, bicarbonate (HCO3-) level of 26mEq/L, base excess (BE) of -2mEq/L, and oxygen saturation (SaO2) of 93%. Her serum creatinine level is elevated at 1.5mg/dL, and her blood urea nitrogen (BUN) level is 39mg/dL. The patient's leukocyte count has decreased from 14.3 to 8.7 thousand cells/microliter.

The patient's blood cultures grew gram-positive cocci in pairs and clusters, which are consistent with oropharyngeal flora. The sputum cultures showed multiple organisms c/w oropharyngeal flora. The urine culture was negative.

The patient's echocardiogram (echo) reveals a normal left atrium size without atrial septal defect. The left ventricular cavity size and global systolic function are normal with an ejection fraction (EF) of >55%. There is mild dilation of the right ventricular cavity with focal hypokinesis of the apical free wall. The aortic root is mildly dilated at the sinus level, and there is severe pulmonary artery systolic hypertension.

The patient's chest X-ray (CXR) shows improvement in the extent of interstitial and peribronchial opacification in the left mid lung field, suggesting mild pulmonary edema. There is also mild calcification of the central adenopathy.

The patient's assessment and plan include rate control for AFib with RVR, ongoing management of acute renal failure, respiratory failure, anemia, respiratory acidosis with metabolic compensation, fever/leukocytosis, sarcoidosis, diabetes type

   Assessment and Plan
   72 yo female h/o DM, HLD, HTN, Afib with RVR, s/p pacemaker and sarcoid
   presents with acute heart failure leading to flash pulmonary edema.
   Patient with multiple episodes of AFib with RVR and hypotension since
   admission, including yesterday evening. She was sent for cath and found
   to have 2 vessel disease, s/p BMS to LAD.  She now is intubated, on
   some sedation, and continues to have volatile blood pressure control
   and episodes of Afib with RVR.
   .
   # RHYTHM: Patient with continued episodes of Afib with RVR with
   hemodynamic instability.
   - Dilt gtt restarted this morning at 10mg/hr, will titrate to maintain
   HR < 110;
   - Since patient has a DDD pacemaker, will not hold back on nodal agents
   as needed for RVR, as patient will be paced out of bradycardia.
   - Will restart Neo gtt as necessary to maintain MAP > 60
   - Consider low dose metroprolol later today if BP stabilizes
   - Monitor on telemetry
   - INR at goal of [**1-29**] today (INR=2.5), will continue home dose of
   coumadin
   - Will continue to rate control per EP
   - Contact outside cardiologist and pulmonologist for ?amiodarone
   # CORONARIES: NSTEMI: found to have 2 vessel disease on cardiac cath
   s/p BMS to the mid LAD. ? whether this was a primary coronary event or
   demand [**1-28**] RVR as pt. had acute heart failure yesterday and still has
   not significantly increased her troponin, would have expected large
   bump by now if infarct large enough to cause LV failure. EKG does
   appear to be c/w s/p anterior infarct.   TTE yesterday showed normal
   EF, focal hypokinesis of apical free wall of RV, and severe pulmonary
   systolic hypertension.
   - Integrillin gtt has now stopped
   - Completed ASA desensitization yesterday
   - Switched Plavix 75 mg to daily instead of [**Hospital1 7**]
   - Simvistatin 80 mg daily
   - Start metroprolol low dose later today if BP tolerates
   - Hold ACE for now, given her hypotension, dye in cath, and bump in
   creatinine
   .
   # PUMP: EF of >55% per TTE yesterday. Current BNP.  Fluid overload
   possibly secondary afib with RVR; this is likely the etiology behind
   her flash pulmonary edema.  She is likely still fluid overloaded, but
   has been hypotensive with MAPs in the 50
s overnight.
   - Will hold diuresis as patient is hypotensive and currently in Afib
   with RVR
   - Once stable, will consider diuresing again
   - Started on stress dose steroids in order to supplement BP given
   possibility of adrenal insufficiency
   .
   # Respiratory Failure: Intubated s/p flash pulmonary edema in OSH;
   possibly secondary to Acute dCHF and complicated by severe pulmonary
   hypertension
   - intubated on AC; can attempt PS again today and ultimately wean from
   vent when HD stable
   - Serial ABG's
   - CXR in AM
   -  Will avoid albuterol [**1-28**] terbutaline allergy
   # Respiratory Acidosis with Metabolic Compensation: Patient h/o COPD on
   home oxygen secondary to sarcoidosis. Acid/Base disturbance likely
   secondary to COPD, as patient may be a CO2 retainer.
   - Continue to monitor with ABG's
   - Adjust major acid/base disturbances with ventilation manipulation
   .
   # Fever/Leukocytosis: Patient still febrile to 102.2 with resolution of
   her leukocytosis (WBC 8.7 this am).  Being treated with Vanc/Cefepime
   and now with positive blood cultures of GPC.  Urine cx neg, sputum
   showed oropharyngeal flora.
   - Continue Vanc/cefepime (Day [**2-2**])
   - Continue Flagyl for possible C Diff infection, as cannot rule that
   out
   - Antibiotics approval received for Vanc/Cefepime
   .
   # Acute Renal Failure: Patient with bump in creatinine today to 1.5
   (from 1.1 yesterday), likely prerenal etiology as consistently
   hypotensive overnight
   - Will calculate FeUrea to evaluated for prerenal etiology
   - Monitor creatinine daily
   # Sarcoidosis: On home O2 3LNC; currently stable; patient intubated
   - Switched to stress dose steroids
   - H/o hypercalcemia -> will continue fosamax q weekly
   .
   # Diabetes type 2: Will hold metformin and glipizide for now.
   Fingersticks 231-332, not well-controlled.
   -Start humulog ISS for more predictable control, will add lantus dose
   for basal insulin
   -FSBS qac and qhs
   .
   # Dyslipidemia: Lipid panel drawn yesterday (see above)
   - Holding zetia for now
   - On simvastatin 80 mg daily
   # Hypothyroidism:
   -Continue Synthroid at 25 mcg daily
   # Depression:
   -Continue Paroxetine 10 mg daily
   # GERD:
   -Start H2 blocker (Famotidine) as PPI interacts with Plavix
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: On tube feeds now
   Glycemic Control:  ISS
   Lines:  Multi Lumen - [**2182-7-16**] 07:06 PM left femoral, A-line, 20
   Gauge - [**2182-7-17**] 12:50 AM
   Consider PICC line.
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT:  Boots, therapeutic INR
   Stress ulcer:  Famotidine 20 mg daily
   VAP:  HOB 30 degrees
   Comments:
   Communication:  Comments:  Husband [**Name (NI) 135**] [**Name (NI) 2415**]: [**Telephone/Fax (1) 8934**] (health
   care proxy)

   Disposition:  CCU for now
Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 72-year-old female with a history of diabetes mellitus, hyperlipidemia, hypertension, atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response, and sarcoidosis. She was admitted with acute heart failure leading to flash pulmonary edema and has been experiencing multiple episodes of atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response and hypotension since admission. The patient underwent cardiac catheterization and was found to have two-vessel coronary artery disease, for which she received a bare-metal stent in the left anterior descending artery.

Medical Complications:
1. Atrial Fibrillation with Rapid Ventricular Response (AFib with RVR): The patient has been experiencing recurrent episodes of AFib with RVR, which has resulted in hemodynamic instability and the need for intubation and mechanical ventilation.
2. Acute Heart Failure: The patient presented with acute heart failure, leading to flash pulmonary edema. She continues to be fluid overloaded and may require diuresis once stable.
3. Coronary Artery Disease (CAD): The patient has been diagnosed with two-vessel CAD, and she underwent percutaneous coronary intervention with the placement of a bare-metal stent in the mid-left anterior descending artery.
4. Respiratory Failure: Due to the flash pulmonary edema and subsequent respiratory failure, the patient required intubation and mechanical ventilation.
5. Fever/Leukocytosis: The patient is febrile and has leukocytosis

Summary:
The patient is a 72-year-old female with a history of diabetes mellitus, hyperlipidemia, hypertension, atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (AFib with RVR), and sarcoidosis. She presents with acute heart failure leading to flash pulmonary edema. The patient has had multiple episodes of AFib with RVR and hypotension since admission, including yesterday evening. She was sent for cardiac catheterization and found to have 2-vessel disease, subsequently receiving bare-metal stent (BMS) placement in the left anterior descending artery (LAD).

The patient is currently intubated and on sedation, with volatile blood pressure control and continued episodes of AFib with RVR. She has a history of COPD on home oxygen secondary to sarcoidosis, and her respiratory status is concerning for respiratory failure due to severe pulmonary hypertension. The patient's acid-base disturbance is likely secondary to COPD, as she may be a CO2 retainer.

Her renal function has deteriorated with an increase in creatinine to 1.5, possibly due to prerenal etiology, dye exposure during catheterization, and septic shock. The patient also has a fever and leukocytosis, which resolved after initiating broad-spectrum antibiotics. Blood cultures grew Gram-positive cocci in clusters, suggestive of a possible hospital-acquired infection.

The patient has a history of diabetes type 2, dyslipidemia, hypothyroidism, depression, and gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). Her medications include various cardiac drugs, antidiabetic agents, lipid-lowering therapy, thyroid hormone replacement, antidepressants, and H2 blockers.

The patient's current plan includes close monitoring of vital signs, particularly blood pressure and heart rate, with titration of antiarrhythmic medications to maintain a heart rate below 110 beats per minute. She will be restarted on diltiazem at a low dose to control her heart rate. The need for amiodarone will be discussed with the cardiologist and pulmonologist. The patient will continue on stress dose steroids due to possible adrenal insufficiency.

Further interventions include weaning from mechanical ventilation, consideration of low-dose metoprolol, and adjusting acid-base disturbances with ventilation manipulation. The patient's fluid overload will be managed carefully, considering the risk of hypotension. Renal function will be monitored closely, and measures will be taken to support renal perfusion.

Overall, the patient's complex medical condition requires close monitoring and a multidisciplinary approach to manage her acute heart failure, respiratory failure, renal failure, infection, and other comorbidities.

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 72-year-old female with a history of diabetes, heart disease, hypertension, atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response, sarcoidosis, and depression. She was admitted with acute heart failure leading to flash pulmonary edema. She has had multiple episodes of atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response since admission. She underwent cardiac catheterization and was found to have two-vessel disease, for which she received bare metal stenting in the left anterior descending artery.

She is currently intubated and sedated, but her rhythm is now in sinus rhythm. The patient has been febrile with a temperature of 100.2°F and leukocytosis (white blood cell count of 15.0), but her white blood cell count has improved to 5.1 today. Blood cultures have grown Staphylococcus coagulase-negative, isolated from one set only. Her sputum culture showed oropharyngeal flora.

The patient's respiratory status has improved, and her breath sounds are greatly improved this morning. She is on mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 450 mL, respiratory rate set at 16, PEEP of 10 cmH2O, FiO2 of 40%, and is maintaining an oxygen saturation of 97%. Her ABG results show a pH of 7.39, PaCO2 of 32 mmHg, and PaO2/FiO2 ratio of 277.

Her renal function has also improved, with a creatinine level down from 1.5 to 1.1. Her blood glucose levels have been unstable, requiring a total of 22 units of Humalog and increasing her Lantus dose by 10 units.

Other assessments and plans include:
- Continue metoprolol 100mg po TID and amiodarone 400mg po BID.
- Monitor on telemetry.
- INR at goal of 2.0.
- Plavix 75 mg daily, simvastatin 80 mg daily, and ASA 325 mg daily for coronary artery disease.
- Hold ACE for now.
- Continue Vanc/cefepime (Day 3) and monitor vancomycin levels.
- Stopped flagyl due to concern for C. difficile.
- Antibiotics approval received for Vanc/cefepime.
- Intubation plan: wean peep and attempt PS again today, ultimately wean from vent when HD stable.
- Serial ABG's and CXR in AM.
- Avoid albuterol and terbutaline allergy.
- Pulmonary follow-up appreciated.
- Lung CT scan w/o contrast per Pulmonary.
- PUMP: EF of >55% per TTE yesterday. Fluid overload possibly secondary to AFib with RVR; this is likely the etiology behind her flash pulmonary edema.
- Once stable, will consider diuresing

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 72-year-old female with a history of diabetes, heart disease, hypertension, atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response, sarcoidosis, and depression. She presented with acute heart failure leading to flash pulmonary edema. The patient has been intubated and sedated, with episodes of atrial fibrillation that were successfully converted back to sinus rhythm using metoprolol and diltiazem.

The patient's current medications include Plavix, simvastatin, ASA, metoprolol, amiodarone, Lantus, Humalog, famotidine, synthroid, paroxetine, and stress dose steroids. She is also receiving tube feeds for nutrition.

The patient's vital signs include a temperature of 100.2°F (38°C), blood pressure ranging from 95/43-168/64 mmHg, heart rate of 67 bpm, respiratory rate of 15 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 97% on mechanical ventilation.

Her lab results show elevated white blood cell count (15.0 K/uL), slightly low hemoglobin (7.7 g/dL), elevated blood glucose (324 mg/dL), and an elevated creatinine level (1.1 mg/dL). The ECG shows a long QTc interval.

The patient has been diagnosed with several medical complications, including coronary artery disease (2-vessel disease), NSTEMI, acute renal failure, anemia, and respiratory failure. She is currently being treated for a GPC bacteremia with vancomycin and cefepime, and her sputum culture showed oropharyngeal flora.

Potential medical complications that can arise include worsening heart failure, arrhythmias, infections (such as C. difficile), pulmonary hypertension, acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), and further deterioration of renal function.

Please note that this summary is based on the provided information, and additional clinical assessment and evaluation may be required for a comprehensive understanding of the patient's condition.

Summary:
The patient is a 72-year-old female with a history of diabetes, hypertension, heart failure, and atrial fibrillation. She presented with acute heart failure leading to flash pulmonary edema. The patient had multiple episodes of atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response and was treated with medications including diltiazem, metoprolol, and amiodarone. She underwent cardiac catheterization and was found to have two-vessel coronary artery disease, for which she received a bare-metal stent in the left anterior descending artery.

The patient is currently intubated and sedated, and her rhythm has been converted to sinus rhythm. However, she still has some QT prolongation on her ECG. Her vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 100.2°F (38°C), heart rate of 67 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 95/43-168/64 mmHg, respiratory rate of 15 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 97% on 40% FiO2. She is receiving mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 450 mL, respiratory rate of 16 breaths per minute, PEEP of 10 cmH2O, and FiO2 of 40%.

The patient has a history of sarcoidosis and is on home oxygen. She also has a history of depression, hypothyroidism, diabetes type 2, dyslipidemia, and GERD. Her laboratory results show

Summary:
Based on the information provided in the progress note, the patient is a 72-year-old female with a history of diabetes mellitus (DM), hypertension (HTN), atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (AFib with RVR), and sarcoidosis. She presents with acute heart failure leading to flash pulmonary edema. The patient has had multiple episodes of AFib with RVR and hypotension since admission.

She was sent for a cardiac catheterization and found to have two-vessel disease, for which she underwent percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) with bare-metal stent placement in the left anterior descending artery (LAD).

The patient is currently intubated and sedated due to respiratory failure. She has been experiencing episodes of atrial fibrillation with fast rates, despite receiving metoprolol and diltiazem. Her blood glucose levels have been consistently high, ranging from 400 to 375 mg/dL, and she has been started on insulin gtt to control her blood sugar levels.

She also has a fever and leukocytosis, with positive blood cultures for coagulase-negative Staphylococcus. She has been treated with vancomycin and cefepime, but her vancomycin levels were high, so the dose was held. Further culture and sensitivity results are pending.

The patient's respiratory status has improved significantly since the removal of a mucus plug yesterday. She is currently on pressure support level

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:

- The patient is a 72-year-old female with a history of diabetes, hypertension, heart failure, and atrial fibrillation. She presented with acute heart failure leading to flash pulmonary edema.
- The patient has been experiencing episodes of atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (AFib with RVR) and hypotension since admission.
- She underwent cardiac catheterization and was found to have two-vessel coronary artery disease, for which she received bare-metal stent placement in the left anterior descending artery.
- The patient is currently intubated and sedated. She has been in atrial fibrillation with rates in the 100s to 120s since midnight, and rate control medications have not been effective in reducing the rate.
- Her blood sugar levels have been elevated, with readings in the 300s. Insulin therapy has been initiated to control her blood sugar levels.
- A CT chest revealed severe sarcoidosis and no evidence of acute infection. There is also a tiny left pleural effusion.
- The patient's respiratory status has improved, but she still has coarse breath sounds on the left side.
- She has leukocytosis with an increased white blood cell count from 5.1 to 13.7. Blood cultures have grown coagulase-negative Staphylococcus, and sputum culture showed oropharyngeal flora.
- The patient has hypernatremia with a sodium

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 72-year-old female with a history of diabetes mellitus, hyperlipidemia, hypertension, atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response, and sarcoidosis. She presents with acute heart failure leading to flash pulmonary edema and has been intubated and sedated. The patient has had multiple episodes of atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response since admission. She underwent coronary angiography and was found to have two-vessel disease, for which she received a bare metal stent in the left anterior descending artery.

Medical Complications:
1. Atrial Fibrillation with Rapid Ventricular Response (AFib with RVR): The patient has experienced several episodes of AFib with RVR since admission. Despite receiving metoprolol and diltiazem, her heart rate remains uncontrolled. She is currently on amiodarone and will be monitored on telemetry.
2. Coronary Artery Disease (CAD): The patient has two-vessel disease and underwent percutaneous coronary intervention with placement of a bare metal stent in the left anterior descending artery.
3. Acute Heart Failure (AHF): The patient's presentation of acute heart failure was likely secondary to AFib with RVR, which resulted in flash pulmonary edema. She has been treated with diuretics and is being monitored closely.
4. Sarcoidosis: The patient has a history of sarcoidosis, and a recent CT scan revealed severe pulmonary involvement

   possibly secondary to Acute dCHF and complicated by severe pulmonary
   hypertension. Extubated yesterday. Doing surprisingly well. Required
   3-4 hours of BIPAP.  .

appreciate recs

   recent CT scan.
   - Continue to treat with Vanc/Cefepime/Flagyl
   - Doesn
t seem volume overloaded on exam, but can try Lasix if patient
   approaching re-intubation
   .
   # RHYTHM:  Patient in afib with rates in the 100s to 130s.
   - Continue Metoprolol 100mg po TID; once she has 5 grams of amio, will
   cut back metoprolol to [**Hospital1 7**]
   - Increase Diltiazem 60mg QID, after 2 doses, will increase Dilt as
   needed for rate control
   - Continue Amiodarone 400mg [**Hospital1 7**]
   - Monitor on telemetry

   - FU INR later today. If less than 1.[**Street Address(2) 9023**] subclavian.
   - Will wean metoprolol to [**Hospital1 7**] at 5 grams of amiodorone is in system,
   today.
   .

   102.  Being treated with Vanc/Cefepime and with positive blood cultures
   of coag negative staph in
 bottles. Repeat blood cultures with no

   flora.
   - Consider intraabdominal infection, no stool cultures, consider
   imaging abdomen
   - Could be constipation-variant C Diff
 will add on Vanc 650mg po q6h
   at this time
   - Consider adding double coverage for anaerobes or pseudomonas,
   although prolonged QT interval
   - Will pull femoral line today, and put in IJ for access this
   afternoon.

   - Fu Blood Cultures (7/22,7/23,[**7-21**]) and Sputum ([**7-17**], [**7-19**]).

   - Continue Vanc/cefepime (Day [**5-2**]); Vanc trough high at 23. Continue
   with current dosing.
   - Will continue Flagyl for possible Diff
   .

   improving. Responds to name this AM.
   - Follow neuro status

 possible DVT?
   - Will get left upper extremity swelling

   .

 typically okay BP
s when not in respiratory distress,

   - Will decrease stress-dose steroids

   - Monitor creatinine daily

   - Rate control her Afib to increased forward flow from heart
   # Sarcoidosis: On home O2 3LNC; currently stable; patient intubated
   - Switched to stress dose steroids
   - H/o hypercalcemia -> will continue fosamax q weekly
   .
   # Dyslipidemia: Lipid panel shows TC 157, TG: 156 HDL 30 LDLc 96; Not
   optimal HDL/LDL level
   - Holding zetia for now
   - Continue simvastatin 80 mg daily
   # Hypothyroidism:
   -Continue Synthroid at 25 mcg daily
   # Depression:
   -Continue Paroxetine 10 mg daily
   # GERD:
   -Start H2 blocker (Famotidine) as PPI interacts with Plavix

Summary:
The patient is a 72-year-old female with a history of diabetes mellitus, hyperlipidemia, hypertension, atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response, sarcoidosis, and depression. She presented with acute heart failure leading to flash pulmonary edema. She has been intubated and placed on mechanical ventilation. The patient has been treated with vancomycin, cefepime, and Flagyl for suspected sepsis. She has also been given insulin gtt for hyperglycemia and stress-dose steroids for possible adrenal insufficiency. 

The patient's vital signs include a temperature of 39°C (102.2°F), heart rate of 112 bpm, blood pressure of 143/65 mmHg, respiratory rate of 24 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 100%. Her current medications include metoprolol, diltiazem, captopril, Plavix, simvastatin, ASA, and Synthroid. 

The patient has a history of coronary artery disease with two-vessel disease and has undergone percutaneous coronary intervention with bare-metal stent placement to the mid-left anterior descending artery. She has been prescribed Plavix, simvastatin, ASA, and metoprolol for her coronary artery disease. 

The patient's laboratory results show leukocytosis with a white blood cell count of 13.7 thousand/mm³, elevated lactate levels of 1.

Summary:
The patient is a 72-year-old female with a medical history of diabetes mellitus, hyperlipidemia, hypertension, atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response, and sarcoidosis. She presented with acute heart failure leading to flash pulmonary edema. She had multiple episodes of atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response and hypotension since admission. She underwent a cardiac catheterization and was found to have 2-vessel disease, for which she received a bare-metal stent in the left anterior descending artery. The patient was intubated due to respiratory failure but was extubated yesterday. She is currently on mechanical ventilation support with BIPAP and has shown improvement. The patient has several medical complications, including fever, leukocytosis, hypernatremia, diabetes type 2, anemia, acute renal failure, sarcoidosis, dyslipidemia, hypothyroidism, depression, and GERD.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient initially required intubation and mechanical ventilation due to flash pulmonary edema secondary to acute decompensated heart failure. Although she has been extubated, there is still a risk of respiratory failure if her heart condition worsens or if she develops any complications related to her pulmonary function.

2. Infection: The patient presented with fever and leukocytosis, indicating a possible infection. Blood cultures showed growth of coag-negative staphylococcus

Summary:
The patient is a 72-year-old female with a history of diabetes mellitus, hyperlipidemia, hypertension, atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response, and sarcoidosis. She presented with acute heart failure leading to flash pulmonary edema. She was intubated and treated with vanc/cefepime and flagyl for possible C. difficile infection. The patient's neurological status has slowly improved, and she is now extubated but requires intermittent BiPAP support. She has multiple medical complications including anemia, acute renal failure, hypernatremia, and hypertension. She also has a history of NSTEMI with two-vessel disease, treated with BMS to the mid LAD. The patient's current medications include metoprolol, diltiazem, captopril, simvastatin, ASA, Plavix, and Synthroid.

   a conservative and noninvasive fashion.  She will remain dnr/dni but

   72 yo female h/o DM, HLD, HTN, Afib with RVR, s/p pacemaker and sarcoid
   presents with acute heart failure leading to flash pulmonary edema.
   Patient with multiple episodes of AFib with RVR and hypotension since
   admission. She was sent for cath and found to have 2 vessel disease,
   s/p BMS to LAD.  Now extubated and breathing comfortably with morphine
   administration.  She is in and out of Afib with rate 110-130, current
   in sinus or paced rhythm with rate 60-70.
   .
   # Respiratory Failure: Intubated s/p flash pulmonary edema in OSH;
   possibly secondary to Acute dCHF and complicated by severe pulmonary
   hypertension. Extubated two days ago with increased respiratory
   distress yesterday afternoon requiring treatment with morphine.  BiPap
   was an option yesterday afternoon but with family
s goals of care in
   mind, a morphine drip was started.
   - Doing well this morning with more comfortable breathing
   - Titrate morphine drip as needed for respiratory distress and comfort
   - Continue Xopenex/Iprotroprium nebs Q4Hours as needed
   .
   # RHYTHM:  Patient now in sinus rhythm, recently in afib with rates in
   the 100s to 130s.
   - Continue Metoprolol 100mg po TID; once she has 5 grams of amio, will
   cut back metoprolol to [**Hospital1 7**]
   - Continue Diltiazem 60mg QID, after 2 doses, will increase Dilt as
   needed for rate control
   - Continue Amiodarone 400mg [**Hospital1 7**]
   - Monitor on telemetry
   - Will wean metoprolol to [**Hospital1 7**] at 5 grams of amiodorone is in system
   (currently at 1600mg)
   .
   # Fever/Leukocytosis: Patient febrile yesterday with rectal temp of
   almost 105.  Likely C Diff in this case, as patient with large smelly
   stool last evening.
   - Will pull femoral line today for comfort and for infection prevention
   - FU cultures
   - Continue fever treatments as needed with Tylenol and cooling blanket
   .
   #Neuro Status: Sedation stopped ([**7-20**]). Pt appears to be slowly
   improving and more lucid with administration of morphine.
   - Follow neuro status
   # Left arm swelling
 possible DVT?
   - Will get left upper extremity swelling
   # CORONARIES: NSTEMI: 2 vessel disease s/p BMS to the mid LAD.
   - Have stopped Plavix 75 mg Daily, Simvastatin 80 mg daily, and ASA 325
   mg Daily
   - Continue Metoprolol 100mg TID for rate control
   - Continue Captopril 6.25 mg [**Hospital1 7**] for blood pressure control
   .
   # Hypertension
 typically okay BP
s when not in respiratory distress,
   added Captopril yesterday.
   - will watch, possible increase in Captopril today in necessary and not
   improving with increased dose of Diltiazem
   # Hypernatremia: Resolved after 2L of D5W. Pt had a 4L Free Water
   deficit.
   - Have stopped labs and fluid repletion
   .
   # Diabetes type 2: Patient recently on insulin drip, now fingersticks
   have stopped in light of goals of care.
   .
   # PUMP: EF of >55% per TTE. Patient even over the last 24 hours. Dose
   not appear to be volume overloaded on exam.
   .
   #Anemia: Last Hct 27, stool gu
   .
   # Acute Renal Failure: Crt stable at 0.9. Most likely secondary to
   hypotension in setting of afib rvr.  FeUrea 8.16% is consistent with
   pre renal etiology..
   - Monitor creatinine daily
   - Continue to support BP for increased renal perfusion
   - Rate control her Afib to increased forward flow from heart
   # Sarcoidosis: On home O2 3LNC; currently stable; patient intubated
   - Switched to stress dose steroids
   - H/o hypercalcemia -> will continue fosamax q weekly
   .
   # Dyslipidemia: Lipid panel shows TC 157, TG: 156 HDL 30 LDLc 96; Not
   optimal HDL/LDL level
   - Holding zetia for now

   # Hypothyroidism:

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 72-year-old female with a history of diabetes mellitus, hyperlipidemia, hypertension, atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response, and sarcoidosis. She presented with acute heart failure leading to flash pulmonary edema. She underwent a cardiac catheterization and was found to have 2-vessel disease, for which she received a bare metal stent in the left anterior descending artery. The patient was extubated two days ago but experienced increased respiratory distress yesterday, which improved with the administration of morphine. She is currently in sinus rhythm with a controlled heart rate and breathing comfortably.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient had flash pulmonary edema and required intubation. Although she was extubated, she experienced increased respiratory distress due to comfort measures only (DNR/DNI). Close monitoring and titration of morphine drip as needed for respiratory distress and comfort are recommended.
2. Rhythm Disturbances: The patient had episodes of atrial fibrillation with rates in the 100s to 130s. Rate control is being managed with metoprolol and diltiazem. Amiodarone is also being continued for rhythm control.
3. Fever/Leukocytosis: The patient had a fever yesterday, likely due to Clostridium difficile infection. Cultures have been obtained, and fever treatments are being provided. The femoral line will be pulled for comfort

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 72-year-old female with a history of diabetes, hypertension, heart disease, and sarcoidosis. She was admitted to the ICU for acute heart failure and flash pulmonary edema. The patient has been intubated and extubated, and is currently experiencing respiratory distress. She has a history of atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response and has undergone a pacemaker placement. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a heart rate of 60-70 bpm and blood pressure ranging from 143/62 mmHg to 180/82 mmHg. Her oxygen saturation is 100%. She has a fever of 104.8 degrees Celsius, which was treated with a cooling blanket, Tylenol, and morphine. The patient's family has decided to pursue comfort care measures, and her code status has been changed to DNR/DNI. 

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory distress and history of flash pulmonary edema indicate a risk of recurrent respiratory failure. Continuous monitoring and management of her respiratory status are essential.
2. Infection: The patient's fever and leukocytosis suggest a possible infection, such as Clostridium difficile (C. diff), especially considering the large smelly stool. Cultures should be obtained, and appropriate treatments should be initiated.
3. Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT): The patient's left arm swelling raises the concern

   administration.  She is in and out of Afib with rate 110-130, current
   in sinus or paced rhythm with rate 60-70. Currently status is DNR/DNI
   and not CMO
   .
   # Respiratory Failure: Intubated s/p flash pulmonary edema in OSH;
   possibly secondary to Acute dCHF and complicated by severe pulmonary
   hypertension. Extubated two days ago with increased respiratory
   distress yesterday afternoon requiring treatment with morphine.  BiPap
   was an option yesterday afternoon but with family
s goals of care in
   mind, a morphine drip was started.
   - Doing well this morning with more comfortable breathing
   - Continue to titrate morphine drip as needed for respiratory distress;
   but will try to decrease morphine to improve wakefulness
   - Continue Xopenex/Iprotroprium nebs Q4Hours as needed
   .

   the 100s to 130s.
   - Continue Metoprolol 100mg po TID; once she has 5 grams of amio, will

   - Will wean metoprolol to [**Hospital1 7**] at 5 grams of amiodorone is in system
   (currently at 1600mg)
   -Re-start Asa and Plavix as patient is no longer CMO. Now DNR/DNI
   .

   almost 105.  Likely C Diff in this case, as patient with large smelly
   stool last evening.
   - Will pull femoral line today for comfort and for infection prevention
   - FU cultures
   - Continue fever treatments as needed with Tylenol and cooling blanket
   - Will send stool for C. diff and empirically start flagyl today
   .
   #Neuro Status: Sedation stopped ([**7-20**]). Pt appears to be slowly
   improving and more lucid with administration of morphine.
   - Follow neuro status
   # Left arm swelling
 possible DVT?

   - Have stopped Plavix 75 mg Daily, Simvastatin 80 mg daily, and ASA 325

   - Continue Captopril 6.25 mg [**Hospital1 7**] for blood pressure control

 typically okay BP

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 72-year-old female with a history of diabetes mellitus, hyperlipidemia, hypertension, atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response, and sarcoidosis. She was admitted to the ICU for acute heart failure leading to flash pulmonary edema. She has been intubated and extubated twice, with increased respiratory distress requiring treatment with morphine. The patient's current status is DNR/DNI and not CMO. She has multiple comorbidities including coronary artery disease, anemia, acute renal failure, dyslipidemia, hypothyroidism, depression, GERD, and possible DVT.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient previously experienced respiratory failure due to flash pulmonary edema, which required intubation. There is a risk of recurrent respiratory distress and failure.
2. Rhythm Disturbances: The patient has a history of atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response. There is a potential for recurrent episodes of AFib with RVR, which can lead to hemodynamic instability.
3. Infection: The patient has fever and leukocytosis, suggesting a possible infection. C. difficile infection is suspected, and empirical treatment with Flagyl has been started.
4. Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT): The patient's left arm swelling may indicate a potential DVT. Further evaluation is needed to confirm this.
5. Anemia: The patient's

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 72-year-old female with a history of diabetes mellitus, hypertension, atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response, sarcoidosis, and coronary artery disease. She presented with acute heart failure leading to flash pulmonary edema and was found to have two-vessel disease, for which she underwent percutaneous coronary intervention with stenting of the left anterior descending artery.

The patient has been experiencing multiple episodes of atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response since admission. She was intubated and placed on BIPAP, but is now comfortable on 3 liters of oxygen via nasal cannula. She appears to be fluid overloaded at this time.

The patient's current vital signs include a temperature of 36.8°C, heart rate of 60 bpm, blood pressure of 135/48 mmHg, respiratory rate of 25 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 100% on face mask. Her current medication regimen includes metoprolol, diltiazem, amiodarone, aspirin, clopidogrel, simvastatin, glargine insulin, and sliding scale insulin.

The patient's laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 17.3 K/uL, hemoglobin of 26.9%, platelet count of 231 K/uL, creatinine of 1.0 mg/dL, blood glucose of 170 mg/dL, and troponin-T of 0.

Summary:
Based on the provided information, the patient is a 72-year-old female with a history of diabetes, hypertension, heart disease, atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (AFib with RVR), sarcoidosis, and coronary artery disease. She presents with acute heart failure leading to flash pulmonary edema and has undergone percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) for two-vessel disease.

The patient's current medical conditions include:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient was previously intubated and placed on BIPAP but is now comfortable on 3L nasal cannula. Morphine and Xopenex/Iprotroprium nebs are administered as needed.

2. Rhythm: The patient was in sinus rhythm but recently experienced episodes of AFib with rates ranging from 100s to 130s. Medications such as metoprolol, diltiazem, and amiodarone are being used for rate control.

3. Fever/Leukocytosis: The patient's high-grade fevers may be secondary to antibiotics or drugs given previously. There is concern for Clostridium difficile (C. diff) infection, and empiric treatment with flagyl has been started. Cultures have been pulled, and the femoral line is being removed.

4. Neuro Status: The patient is completely interactive and appropriate.

5. Left arm swelling: No thrombus was identified on the left upper extremity ultrasound. Swelling remains stable.

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 72-year-old female with a history of diabetes, hypertension, heart disease, and atrial fibrillation. She was admitted with acute heart failure leading to flash pulmonary edema. The patient underwent a cardiac catheterization and was found to have two-vessel disease, for which she received a bare-metal stent to the left anterior descending artery. She is now extubated and breathing comfortably with the administration of morphine. The patient's current rhythm is sinus, although she has had episodes of atrial fibrillation with rates in the 100s to 130s. Her blood pressure is stable, but she has experienced hypotension since admission. The patient has been prescribed multiple medications including metoprolol, diltiazem, amiodarone, aspirin, Plavix, simvastatin, and captopril. She also has a diagnosis of anemia, sarcoidosis, dyslipidemia, hypothyroidism, depression, and gastroesophageal reflux disease. The patient's family wishes for her to go to rehab, but her medical condition requires palliative care, and she has chosen a DNR/DNI status. 

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's recent history of respiratory distress and previous intubation indicate a risk of respiratory failure. Close monitoring of oxygen saturation levels and respiratory effort is necessary.
2. Rhythm Disturbances: The patient's history of
